SHALL WE BOYCOTT?
Editor News-Letter,
Dear Sir:
After the Maryland-Hopkins
game last Saturday a number of
Hopkins men attended the show
at the Century Roof. During the
course of the evening (9-11 P. M.)
a number of Hopkins yells and
songs were given, to which no objection was expressed by the
management. However, at 11
o'clock, or there about, Mr.
Charles E. Whitehurst, one of the
proprietors, accompanied by a
number of policemen, came over
to the table at which most of the
Hopkins men ,ere seated and
proceeded to tell the boys with
the minimum of Politeness and
the maximum of profanity that if
they could not "shut up they
could get out" and he would furnish some assistance in that direction.
All noise stopped and there
was no further objection raised
to our deportment during the remainder of the evening. But
every Hopkins man felt very
keenly with a high degree of in-

dignation the uncalled for manner and methods of Mr. Whitehurst.
Before leaving the Roof I made
it a point to see Mr. Whitehurst
and explain to him that his action
was greatly resentea i?y all the
Hopkins men. To this he argued
in his characteristic profane language, which was undoubtedly
emphatic, that he did not want
any Hopkins men up on the Century Roof! He made it clear that
he did not need the money resulting from Hopkins patronage, and
that he did not want it.
To quote Mr. Whitehurst exactly would not furnish fit material for printing in our esteemed
publication, but I trust that Hopkins students, graduates and
friends will comply with his very
earnest request and leave the
Century Roof for the class of people to which he prefers to cater.
That the patrons of the Roof
did not object to the cheers or behavior of the Hopkins men is evidenced by the fact that the actions of Mr. Whitehurst in summoning the policemen was soundly hissed by the audience.
Truly yours,
Daniel E. Klein

UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII HAS
FOOTBALL TEAM
The University of Hawaii which
was organized in 1920 numbered
last year some 450 students.
As a regular university, one of
its first cares was for the football
situation. As there are unfortunately no other universities in Hawaii, intercollegiate football necessitated the importation of a team
from the mainland. The Universities of Oregon and Nevada kindly
obliged, and this year Pomona,
California, will try its luck with the
new university.
But football is not everything
in this world. Hawaii University
this year has begun the issue of a
college paper, which will compare
favorably with almost any similar
publication on the mainland. In
the first issue is a most interesting
article on Professor Richard Wrenshall, who is working on a specific for leprosy, and the international difficulties which are retarding its development.
Perhaps American college papers
would be most interested in two
letters, one from W. R. Farrington, Governor of Hawaii, and one

THIS is the month when the sun is outshone, and
1 we mortals draw greater warmth and sustenance
from that homely provender —mince pie.
It is the warmth of the holiday spirit, which causes
human hearts to glow when temperatures are lowest.
Mother's cooking the family united — Christmas
trees and crackling logs—what would this world be
without them?
In promoting the family good cheer the college
man's part is such that modesty often blinds him to it.
It would hardly occur to the glee club man to sing
over the songs of Alma Mater for the still Dearer
One at home.
The football man would scarcely suspect that his
younger brother is dying to have him drop-kick for
the "fellers".
The Prom leader would not presume to think that
among those sisters who have been waiting to share
his agility at fox-trot may be his own sister.
And in general, college men would scorn to believe
thatany conversational prowess they might possess on
books, professors or campus activities could possibly
interest a certain Gentleman Who Foots the Bills.
Butjust try it, all of you. The welcome you get
will warm the cockles of your heart.
This suggestion, amid sighs as they look back
across the years, is the best way a bunch of old grads
here know of wishing you "Merry Christmas".

SHALL WE BOYCOTT?
Editor News-Letter,
Dear Sir:
After the Maryland-Hopkins
game last Saturday a number of
Hopkins men attended the show
at the Century Roof. During the
course of the evening (9-11 P. M.)
a number of Hopkins yells and
songs were given, to which no objection was expressed by the
management. However, at 11
o'clock, or there about, Mr.
Charles E. Whitehurst, one of the
proprietors, accompanied by a
number of policemen, came over
to the table at which most of the
Hopkins men ,ere seated and
proceeded to tell the boys with
the minimum of Politeness and
the maximum of profanity that if
they could not "shut up they
could get out" and he would furnish some assistance in that direction.
All noise stopped and there
was no further objection raised
to our deportment during the remainder of the evening. But
every Hopkins man felt very
keenly with a high degree of in-

dignation the uncalled for manner and methods of Mr. Whitehurst.
Before leaving the Roof I made
it a point to see Mr. Whitehurst
and explain to him that his action
was greatly resentea i?y all the
Hopkins men. To this he argued
in his characteristic profane language, which was undoubtedly
emphatic, that he did not want
any Hopkins men up on the Century Roof! He made it clear that
he did not need the money resulting from Hopkins patronage, and
that he did not want it.
To quote Mr. Whitehurst exactly would not furnish fit material for printing in our esteemed
publication, but I trust that Hopkins students, graduates and
friends will comply with his very
earnest request and leave the
Century Roof for the class of people to which he prefers to cater.
That the patrons of the Roof
did not object to the cheers or behavior of the Hopkins men is evidenced by the fact that the actions of Mr. Whitehurst in summoning the policemen was soundly hissed by the audience.
Truly yours,
Daniel E. Klein

UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII HAS
FOOTBALL TEAM
The University of Hawaii which
was organized in 1920 numbered
last year some 450 students.
As a regular university, one of
its first cares was for the football
situation. As there are unfortunately no other universities in Hawaii, intercollegiate football necessitated the importation of a team
from the mainland. The Universities of Oregon and Nevada kindly
obliged, and this year Pomona,
California, will try its luck with the
new university.
But football is not everything
in this world. Hawaii University
this year has begun the issue of a
college paper, which will compare
favorably with almost any similar
publication on the mainland. In
the first issue is a most interesting
article on Professor Richard Wrenshall, who is working on a specific for leprosy, and the international difficulties which are retarding its development.
Perhaps American college papers
would be most interested in two
letters, one from W. R. Farrington, Governor of Hawaii, and one

THIS is the month when the sun is outshone, and
1 we mortals draw greater warmth and sustenance
from that homely provender —mince pie.
It is the warmth of the holiday spirit, which causes
human hearts to glow when temperatures are lowest.
Mother's cooking the family united — Christmas
trees and crackling logs—what would this world be
without them?
In promoting the family good cheer the college
man's part is such that modesty often blinds him to it.
It would hardly occur to the glee club man to sing
over the songs of Alma Mater for the still Dearer
One at home.
The football man would scarcely suspect that his
younger brother is dying to have him drop-kick for
the "fellers".
The Prom leader would not presume to think that
among those sisters who have been waiting to share
his agility at fox-trot may be his own sister.
And in general, college men would scorn to believe
thatany conversational prowess they might possess on
books, professors or campus activities could possibly
interest a certain Gentleman Who Foots the Bills.
Butjust try it, all of you. The welcome you get
will warm the cockles of your heart.
This suggestion, amid sighs as they look back
across the years, is the best way a bunch of old grads
here know of wishing you "Merry Christmas".
